title: Algebra I
teaser: Students explore relationships between quantities, descriptive statistics, linear and exponential functions, polynomial and quadratic expressions.

children.title: Relationships Between Quantities and Reasoning with Equations and Their Graphs
children.teaser: Students analyze and explain precisely the process of solving an equation.

children.title: Introduction to Functions Studied This Year- Graphing Stories
children.teaser: Students explore functions.

children.title: Graphs of Piecewise Linear Functions
children.teaser: Students choose/interpret the scale, the origin for the graph and graph the piecewise linear function.

children.title: Graphs of Quadratic Functions
children.teaser: Students represent graphically a nonlinear relationship between two quantities and interpret features of the graph.

children.title: Graphs of Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students choose and interpret the scale on a graph to appropriately represent an exponential function.

children.title: Analyzing Graphs—Water Usage During a Typical Day at School
children.teaser: Students refine their skills in interpreting the meaning of features appearing in graphs.

children.title: Two Graphing Stories
children.teaser: Students interpret the meaning of the point of intersection of two graphs.

children.title: The Structure of Expressions
children.teaser: Students define what it means for two algebraic expressions to be equivalent.

children.title: Algebraic Expressions-The Distributive Property
children.teaser: Students use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite/use distributive property.

children.title: Algebraic Expressions-The Commutative and Associative Properties
children.teaser: Commutative/Associative properties are used to recognize structure within expressions and prove equivalency of expressions.

children.title: Adding and Subtracting Polynomials
children.teaser: Students understand that the sum or difference of two polynomials produces another polynomial.

children.title: Multiplying Polynomials
children.teaser: Students understand that the product of two polynomials produces another polynomial; students multiply polynomials.

children.title: Solving Equations and Inequalities
children.teaser: Students explain, justify, and evaluate their reasoning as they strategize methods for solving linear and non-linear equations.

children.title: True and False Equations
children.teaser: Students find values to assign to variables in equations that make the equations true statements.

children.title: Solutions Sets for Equations and Inequalities
children.teaser: Students understand the commutative, associate, and distributive properties as identities.

children.title: Solving Equations
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the formal process of solving an equation.

children.title: Some Potential Dangers When Solving Equations
children.teaser: Students learn if-then moves using properties of equality to solve equations.

children.title: Solving Inequalities
children.teaser: Learning if-then moves using addition/multiplication properties of inequality to solve inequalities and graph solution.

children.title: Solution Sets of Two or More Equations
children.teaser: Students describe the solution set of two equations (or inequalities) joined by “and” or “or”

children.title: Solving and Graphing Inequalities Joined by "And" or "Or"
children.teaser: Students solve two inequalities joined by “and” or “or” then graph solution on number line.

children.title: Equations Involving Factored Expressions
children.teaser: Students solve factored or easily factorable equations.

children.title: Equations Involving a Variable Expression in the Denominator
children.teaser: Students interpret equations.

children.title: Rearranging Formulas
children.teaser: Students learn to think of some of the letters in formulas as constants.

children.title: Solution Sets to Equations with Two Variables
children.teaser: Students identify solutions to two-variable equations and represent graphically.

children.title: Solution Sets to Inequalities with Two Variables
children.teaser: Students interpret inequality symbols to determine which portion of the coordinate plane is shaded.

children.title: Solution Sets to Simultaneous Equations
children.teaser: Students solve systems of linear equations/inequalities either algebraically or graphically.

children.title: Solution Sets to Simultaneous Equations (Continued)
children.teaser: Students create systems of equations that have the same solution set as a given system.

children.title: Applications of Systems of Equations and Inequalities
children.teaser: Students use systems of equations/inequalities to solve contextual problems.

children.title: Creating Equations to Solve Problems
children.teaser: Students create equations and inequalities and graph.

children.title: Solving Problems in Two Ways-Rates and Algebra
children.teaser: Students compare the numerical approach to the algebraic approach.

children.title: Recursive Challenge Problem-The Double and Add 5 Game
children.teaser: Students learn the meaning and notation of recursive sequences in a modeling setting.

children.title: Recursive Challenge Problem-The Double and Add 5 Game (Continued)
children.teaser: Students create equations and inequalities to solve a modeling problem.

children.title: Federal Income Tax
children.teaser: Students create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems.

children.title: Descriptive Statistics
children.teaser: Students work with data distributions of various shapes, centers, and spreads.

children.title: Shapes and Centers of Distributions
children.teaser: Students observe and describe data distributions.

children.title: Distributions and Their Shapes
children.teaser: Students recognize that a first step in interpreting data is making sense of the context.

children.title: Describing the Center of a Distribution
children.teaser: Students calculate the mean of a data set and the median of a data set.

children.title: Estimating Centers and Interpreting the Mean as a Balance Point
children.teaser: Students estimate the mean and median of a distribution on a dot plot or a histogram.

children.title: Describing Variability and Comparing Distributions
children.teaser: Students describe distributions in terms of shape, measure of center, and variability from the center.

children.title: Summarizing Deviations from the Mean
children.teaser: Students interpret deviations.

children.title: Measuring Variability for Symmetrical Distributions
children.teaser: Students calculate the standard deviation for a set of data.

children.title: Interpreting the Standard Deviation
children.teaser: Students compare the relative variability of distributions using standard deviations.

children.title: Measuring Variability for Skewed Distributions (Interquartile Range)
children.teaser: Students identify outliers in a data distribution.

children.title: Comparing Distributions
children.teaser: Students compare two or more distributions.

children.title: Categorical  Data on Two Variables
children.teaser: Students understand the distinction between association causal relationship between two variables.

children.title: Summarizing Bivariate Categorical Data
children.teaser: Students distinguish between categorical data and numerical data

children.title: Summarizing Bivariate Categorical Data with Relative Frequencies
children.teaser: Students construct a relative frequency table and interpret relative frequencies.

children.title: Conditional Relative Frequencies and Association
children.teaser: Students calculate and interpret conditional relative frequencies from two-way frequency tables.

children.title: Numerical Data on Two Variables
children.teaser: Students analyze relationships between two quantitative variables.

children.title: Relationships Between Two Numerical Variables
children.teaser: Students distinguish between various  scatter plots.

children.title: Relationships Between Two Numerical Variables (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use an equation given as a model for a nonlinear relationship to answer questions.

children.title: Modeling Relationships with a Line
children.teaser: Students use technology to determine the least squares regression line from given set of data.

children.title: Interpreting Residuals from a Line
children.teaser: Students predict values for a given data set.

children.title: More on Modeling Relationships with a Line
children.teaser: Students use the least squares line to predict values for a given data set.

children.title: Analyzing Residuals
children.teaser: Students construct the residual plot for a given data set.

children.title: Analyzing Residuals (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use a graphing calculator to construct the residual plot for a given data set.

children.title: Interpreting Correlation
children.teaser: Students use technology to determine the value of the correlation coefficient for given data set.

children.title: Analyzing Data Collected on Two Variables
children.teaser: Students use data to develop a poster that involves the focus standards.

children.title: Linear and Exponential Functions
children.teaser: Students explore function notation and the concepts of domain and range.

children.title: Linear and Exponential Sequences
children.teaser: Students are introduced to the formal notation of functions.

children.title: Integer Sequences-Should You Believe in Patterns
children.teaser: Students examine sequences and are introduced to the notation used to describe them.

children.title: Recursive Formulas for Sequences
children.teaser: Students write recursive and explicit formulas for sequences.

children.title: Arithmetic and Geometric Sequences
children.teaser: Students learn the structure of arithmetic and geometric sequences.

children.title: Why Do Banks Pay YOU to Provide Their Services?
children.teaser: Students compare the rate of change for simple and compound interest.

children.title: The Power of Exponential Growth
children.teaser: Students are able to model with and solve problems involving exponential formulas.

children.title: Exponential Growth-U.S. Population and World Population
children.teaser: Students compare linear and exponential models of population growth.

children.title: Exponential Decay
children.teaser: Students describe and analyze exponential decay models.

children.title: Functions and Their Graphs
children.teaser: Students recognize, evaluate, and interpret functions.

children.title: Why Stay with Whole Numbers?
children.teaser: Students use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements.

children.title: Representing, Naming, and Evaluating Functions
children.teaser: Students evaluate functions for inputs in their domains; interpret statements that use function notation.

children.title: Representing, Naming, and Evaluating Functions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements

children.title: The Graph of a Function
children.teaser: Students understand set builder notation for the graph of a real-valued function.

children.title: The Graph of the Equation 𝑦 = 𝑓(𝑥)
children.teaser: Students understand the meaning of the graph of functions.

children.title: Interpreting the Graph of a Function
children.teaser: Students create tables and graphs of functions and interpret key features.

children.title: Linear and Exponential Models-Comparing Growth Rates
children.teaser: Students compare linear/exponential models.

children.title: Transformations of Functions
children.teaser: Students learn a graphical approach to circumventing complex algebraic solutions to equations in one variable.

children.title: Piecewise Functions
children.teaser: Students examine the features of piecewise functions.

children.title: Graphs Can Solve Equations Too
children.teaser: Students discover that equations can be solved algebraically or visually.

children.title: Four Interesting Transformations of Functions (Part 1)
children.teaser: Students examine how vertical translations correspond to changes in the equation.

children.title: Four Interesting Transformations of Functions (Part 2)
children.teaser: Students examine how horizontal translations correspond to changes in the equation.

children.title: Four Interesting Transformations of Functions (Part 3)
children.teaser: Students examine horizontal scaling.

children.title: Four Interesting Transformations of Functions (Part 4)
children.teaser: Students apply understanding of transformations of functions and graphs to piecewise functions.

children.title: Using Functions and Graphs to Solve Problems
children.teaser: Students create equations and functions to model situations.

children.title: Comparing Linear and Exponential Models Again
children.teaser: Students create models and understand the differences between linear and exponential models.

children.title: Modeling an Invasive Species Population
children.teaser: Students use modeling to solve real-world function problems.

children.title: Newton's Law of Cooling
children.teaser: Students apply transformations through modeling.

children.title: Piecewise and Step Functions in Context
children.teaser: Students create piecewise and step functions that relate to real-life situations.

children.title: Polynomial and Quadratic Expressions, Equations, and Functions
children.teaser: Students explore polynomial and quadratic functions.

children.title: Quadratic Expressions, Equations, Functions, and Their Connection to Rectangles
children.teaser: Students factor polynomial expressions and solve basic polynomial equations.

children.title: Multiplying and Factoring Polynomial Expressions
children.teaser: Students use polynomial expressions as side lengths of polygons and find area by multiplying.

children.title: Multiplying and Factoring Polynomial Expressions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students understand that factoring reverses the multiplication process.

children.title: Advanced Factoring Strategies for Quadratic Expressions
children.teaser: Students develop strategies for factoring quadratic.

children.title: Advanced Factoring Strategies for Quadratic Expressions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students develop additional strategies for factorization of quadratics.

children.title: The Zero Product Property
children.teaser: Students solve complex one-variable equations which may need algebraic manipulation, including factoring.

children.title: Solving Basic One-Variable Quadratic Equations
children.teaser: Students use appropriate and efficient strategies to find solutions to basic quadratic equations.

children.title: Creating and Solving Quadratic Equations in One Variable
children.teaser: Students interpret word problems to create equations in one variable and solve them.

children.title: Exploring the Symmetry in Graphs of Quadratic Functions
children.teaser: Students explore key features of graphs of quadratic functions.

children.title: Graphing Quadratic Functions from Factored Form, f(x)=a(x-m)(x-n)
children.teaser: Students use the factored form of a quadratic equation to construct a rough graph.

children.title: Interpreting Quadratic Functions from Graphs and Tables
children.teaser: Students interpret quadratic functions from graphs and tables.

children.title: Using Different Form for Quadratic Functions
children.teaser: Students transform quadratic functions from standard form to vertex form.

children.title: Completing the Square
children.teaser: Students rewrite quadratic expressions given in standard form.

children.title: Completing the Square (Continued)
children.teaser: Students recognize cases for which factored or completed-square form is most efficient to use.

children.title: Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square
children.teaser: Students solve quadratic equations, including those with a coefficient other than 1.

children.title: Deriving the Quadratic Formula
children.teaser: Students complete the square for a general quadratic equation.

children.title: Using the Quadratic Formula
children.teaser: Students solve quadratic equations that cannot be easily factored.

children.title: Graphing Quadratic Equations from the Vertex Form, 𝑦 = 𝑎(𝑥−h)^2+𝑘
children.teaser: Students graph simple quadratic equations of the completed-square or vertex form.

children.title: Graphing Quadratic Functions from the Standard Form, f(x)=ax^2+bx+c
children.teaser: Students graph a variety of quadratic functions using standard form.

children.title: Function Transformations and Modeling
children.teaser: Students explore the families of functions related to parent functions.

children.title: Graphing Cubic, Square Root, and Cube Root Functions
children.teaser: Students compare the basic quadratic (parent) function to the square root function.

children.title: Translating Graphs of Functions
children.teaser: Students recognize and use parent functions.

children.title: Stretching and Shrinking Graphs of Functions
children.teaser: Students use parent functions for absolute value, quadratic, square root, and cube root.

children.title: Transformations of the Quadratic Parent Function, f(x)=x^2
children.teaser: Students make a connection between the symbolic forms of quadratic equations and the vertex form.

children.title: Comparing Quadratic, Square, and Cube Root Functions Represented Differently
children.teaser: Students complete a comparative analysis of quadratic functions.

children.title: Modeling with Quadratic Functions
children.teaser: Students write the quadratic function described verbally in a given context.

children.title: Modeling with Quadratic Functions (Continued)
children.teaser: Students create a quadratic function from a data set based on a contextual situation.

children.title: A Synthesis of Modeling with Equations and Functions
children.teaser: Students practice writing, comparing, and graphing functions and interpreting the parameters of an equation.

children.title: Elements of Modeling
children.teaser: Students represent graphs, data sets, or verbal descriptions using explicit expressions.

children.title: Analyzing a Graph
children.teaser: Students recognize the function type, interpret key features of the graph, and create an equation.

children.title: Analyzing a Data Set
children.teaser: Students recognize linear, quadratic, and exponential functions when presented as a data set or sequence.

children.title: Analyzing a Verbal Description
children.teaser: Students make sense of a contextual situation.

children.title: Completing the Modeling Cycle
children.teaser: Students complete the modeling cycle for a real-world contextual problem.

children.title: Modeling a Context from a Graph
children.teaser: Students create a two-variable equation that models the graph from a context.

children.title: Modeling from a Sequence
children.teaser: Students recognize when a table of values represents an arithmetic or geometric sequence.

children.title: Modeling a Context from Data
children.teaser: Students write equations modeling data, which can be represented with linear, quadratic, or exponential functions.

children.title: Modeling a Context from Data (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use linear, quadratic, and exponential functions to model data from tables.

children.title: Modeling a Context from a Verbal Description
children.teaser: Students model functions described verbally in a given context using graphs, tables, or algebraic representations.

children.title: Modeling a Context from a Verbal Description (Continued)
children.teaser: Students use graphs to interpret the function represented by the equation in terms of context.
